Award.AwardTitle: Direct Measurements of Fundamental Sintering Parameters in Nanoparticles
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY: The intellectual merit of this proposal focuses on the fundamental mechanisms that influence the low temperature (<300˚C) sintering of metallic nanoparticles (NPs). Existing models cannot accurately predict the sintering response of NPs at low temperatures. A synergistic combination of state-of-the art processing and in-situ and ex-situ transmission electron microscopy will be employed to investigate sintering of NPs. Pairs of NPs that are free of dispersants will be produced to meet the stringent requirements necessary for this study. This is crucial as the presence of organic dispersants that are typically present on the surfaces of NPs interfere with the intrinsic sintering behavior of the NPs at low temperatures. Second, a state-of-the-art, aberration-corrected TEM/STEM equipped with a novel heating stage for in-situ sintering experiments will be utilized to perform real-time measurements on NPs of neck growth, interparticle distance and boundary mobility. Third, correlations will be made between the studies performed on pairs of NPs with studies using realistic, three-dimensional particle morphologies in thick films. These experiments will increase fundamental understanding of sintering in metallic nanoparticles by 1) Determining how particle size, temperature, and particle geometry influence sintering mechanisms in NPs, 2) Measuring the influence of particle size, temperature, and particle geometry on surface or grain boundary diffusivity and grain boundary mobility in NPs, 3) Identifying the role of defects, particularly twins on the sintering behavior of NPs, and 4) Determining the extent to which the electron beam, influences the measured mass transport rates during in situ TEM/STEM experiments.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY: Thick film materials are currently used in a large number of diverse applications including many electronic devices. The market for these devices is growing rapidly and improvements in technologies are critical for these advancements. For example, according to III-Vs Review (Vol. 17, no 2. March 2004, pg 7.), the market for thick films was estimated at $16.8 billion in 2008 with significant growth likely in the future due to the increases in portable telecommunication devices. Current technologies require processing temperatures of up to 800˚C, which severely restricts the materials that can be utilized and drives up costs significantly. In addition, there are a number of new technologies that would benefit from reduced processing temperatures for thick films including biosensors and thick film solar cells. The proposed research focuses on understanding the fundamental mechanisms that would allow the processing of thick films of metallic nanoparticles at temperatures less than 300˚C. The proposed activities encompass outreach activities offering deaf students, who are highly underrepresented in science and engineering, research opportunities related to the proposed work. A recently established partnership between UT Austin and the Texas School for the Deaf is in need of additional research projects in which students can be placed and the proposed activities will provide a critical mass of projects and students that will significantly benefit this program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Patterned, thick film, metallic conductors are traditionally produced by screen printing for diverse applications including photovoltaics, pacemakers, RFID antennas, and touch panels. This process requires deposition of metallic powder particles into thick films. To achieve high density, is necessary to sinter the particles so that they form a continuous solid and this process typically requires temperatures of 700-900░C. As new applications for thick film conductors emerge, the need for lower temperatures is a major limiting factor. The ability to produce higher conductivity metallic lines at sintering temperatures of less than 300 ░C would open the door to the development of novel devices that utilize low cost but temperature-sensitive substrates.

 A reduction in sintering temperature with particle size is predicted from theoretical models. However, these models do not predict the experimentally measured particle size dependence on sintering temperatures for NPs. The intellectual merit of this grant was aimed at understanding the fundamental mechanisms governing sintering of metallic NPs at low temperatures.

Challenges for conducting this research were that 1) Most nanoparticles contain organic coatings on the surface of the nanoparticles.  Organic coatings interfere with the sintering process and make it impossible to obtain information about the intrinsic mass transfer rates during sintering and 2) Most sintering studies are conducted post-mortem; as a result details about the sintering process can be missed. To address these issues we used a combination of a novel aerosol synthesis method in which no organic coatings are added to the process and in situ heating studies using a transmission electron microscope (TEM) equipped with a specialized heater.  This allowed us to observe in real time the sintering process.  Our specific goals were to 1) determine how particle size, temperature, and particle geometry influence sintering mechanisms in NPs.┐ 2) measure the influence of particle size, temperature, and particle geometry on surface or grain boundary diffusivity and grain boundary mobility. ┐3) Identify the role of defects, particularly twins on the sintering behavior of NPs. ┐4) Determine the extent to which the electron beam, influences the measured mass transport rates during in situ TEM experiments 5) Quantify the influences of surface coatings such as carbon on sintering.

The broader impacts of this grant focused on educational activities designed to motivate historically under-represented students to consider entering STEM majors by introducing under-represented high school students to research in nanomaterials. Two programs were employed to achieve these goals 1) Two high school students from the Texas School for the Deaf were two students were employed as researchers in the 1st year of the grant in our labs 2) In the last year of our grant we participated in UT Austin’s Alice in Wonderland program for female high school students. An Alice internship allows participants work in research labs in Physics or Engineering. In addition, a short course is offered at the start of the program in June. This course, taught by UT graduate students, covers subjects from computer modeling and quantum mechanics to scanning tunneling microscopy and thin film growth.

We have utilized the LAMA process to produce samples for in situ TEM studies. We determined that there were discrepancies between the temperatures reported by the heating stage and actual temperatures under the electron beam, primarily due to heating from the beam, and quantified those discrepancies.

We have conducted in situ heating experiments with Ag and Pt in the TEM to measure sintering rates as a function of particle size, temperature, and particle geometry.┐ We then used this information to determine the influence of par...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Patterned, thick film, metallic conductors are traditionally produced by screen printing for diverse applications including photovoltaics, pacemakers, RFID antennas, and touch panels. This process requires deposition of metallic powder particles into thick films. To achieve high density, is necessary to sinter the particles so that they form a continuous solid and this process typically requires temperatures of 700-900░C. As new applications for thick film conductors emerge, the need for lower temperatures is a major limiting factor. The ability to produce higher conductivity metallic lines at sintering temperatures of less than 300 ░C would open the door to the development of novel devices that utilize low cost but temperature-sensitive substrates. A reduction in sintering temperature with particle size is predicted from theoretical models. However, these models do not predict the experimentally measured particle size dependence on sintering temperatures for NPs. The intellectual merit of this grant was aimed at understanding the fundamental mechanisms governing sintering of metallic NPs at low temperatures. Challenges for conducting this research were that 1) Most nanoparticles contain organic coatings on the surface of the nanoparticles. Organic coatings interfere with the sintering process and make it impossible to obtain information about the intrinsic mass transfer rates during sintering and 2) Most sintering studies are conducted post-mortem; as a result details about the sintering process can be missed. To address these issues we used a combination of a novel aerosol synthesis method in which no organic coatings are added to the process and in situ heating studies using a transmission electron microscope (TEM) equipped with a specialized heater. This allowed us to observe in real time the sintering process. Our specific goals were to 1) determine how particle size, temperature, and particle geometry influence sintering mechanisms in NPs.┐ 2) measure the influence of particle size, temperature, and particle geometry on surface or grain boundary diffusivity and grain boundary mobility. ┐3) Identify the role of defects, particularly twins on the sintering behavior of NPs. ┐4) Determine the extent to which the electron beam, influences the measured mass transport rates during in situ TEM experiments 5) Quantify the influences of surface coatings such as carbon on sintering. The broader impacts of this grant focused on educational activities designed to motivate historically under-represented students to consider entering STEM majors by introducing under-represented high school students to research in nanomaterials. Two programs were employed to achieve these goals 1) Two high school students from the Texas School for the Deaf were two students were employed as researchers in the 1st year of the grant in our labs 2) In the last year of our grant we participated in UT AustinÆs Alice in Wonderland program for female high school students. An Alice internship allows participants work in research labs in Physics or Engineering. In addition, a short course is offered at the start of the program in June. This course, taught by UT graduate students, covers subjects from computer modeling and quantum mechanics to scanning tunneling microscopy and thin film growth. We have utilized the LAMA process to produce samples for in situ TEM studies. We determined that there were discrepancies between the temperatures reported by the heating stage and actual temperatures under the electron beam, primarily due to heating from the beam, and quantified those discrepancies. We have conducted in situ heating experiments with Ag and Pt in the TEM to measure sintering rates as a function of particle size, temperature, and particle geometry.┐ We then used this information to determine the influence of particle size, temperature, and particle geometry on surface or grain boundary diffusivity and grain boundary mobility.
